prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: In Roman times, slave labour was the central source of wealth. Roman law provided that a master had recourse against a third party who induced his or her servant to disclose information pertaining to the master's commercial affairs. The master was entitled to double damages on the theory that the value of the slave was reduced as well as the fact that losses were incurred as a result of the divulgence of the trade secret. This protection focused on the relationship between master and servant.

Roman law also protected the right to confidential information regarding dyeing and pottery processes.[1] However, it did not recognize monopolies such as patent or property rights over most intangible property.[2] If an author wrote a work on paper belonging to another, the work was considered to belong to the owner of the paper. The reasoning was that the author's reward was fame, not money.[3] The only known exception to this rule was the case of visual works of art. If a picture or painting was done on paper belonging to another, the work remained the property of the artist. It is not known why this exception was made for paintings.
